thread.title: Phillies avoid 100th loss by beating Marlins
thread.title_full: Phillies avoid 100th loss by beating Marlins

author: Jake Kaplan,
title: Phillies avoid 100th loss by beating Marlins
text:
The first year of a rebuilding project that began in earnest with the December trade of Jimmy Rollins came to an end Sunday afternoon at Citizens Bank Park.
It culminated in the Phillies' 63d win, by 7-2 over the Miami Marlins, as they avoided the franchise's first 100-loss season since 1961. Their season went in the books with 99 losses, the most for a Phillies team since 1969.
Aaron Altherr broke open the season finale with a bases-clearing triple in the seventh inning. David Buchanan closed out a struggle-filled season with a strong outing. Ken Giles pitched a scoreless ninth.
Buchanan, who accounted for two of the Phillies' 10 hits, allowed only one earned run over 6 2/3 innings. The 26-year-old righthander struck out seven and walked only one. The Marlins scored their first run when Jeff Francoeur a dropped a two-out line drive.
More coverage Box score: Phillies 7, Marlins 2 Download FREE Philly Sports Now app for iPhone! Buy Phillies jerseys and other gear WATCH: Daily fantasy baseball updates Marlins second baseman Dee Gordon secured the National League batting title with a three-hit afternoon. He roped a double on Buchanan's first pitch of the game and homered in the third. At game's end, his .333 average was .004 better than Washington's Bryce Harper.
Ichiro Suzuki, the future Hall of Fame outfielder, pitched the ninth inning for the Marlins, the 41-year-old's first appearance on a major-league mound. He allowed a run on doubles by Odubel Herrera and Darnell Sweeney. Herrera's was his team-leading 30th of the season, the most by a Phillies rookie since Scott Rolen in 1997. The Rule 5 draft pick capped his impressive campaign with a .297 batting average.
The Phillies announced an attendance of 21,734 for the finale, bringing their season total to 1,831,080. The mark is the team's lowest home attendance for a season since 2002 (the penultimate year at Veterans Stadium) and 592,772 fewer than last season.
